title-group.article-title: New Larval Host Records for North American Cerambycidae (Coleoptera)

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Neobellamira delicata australis Linsley and Chemsak.
Quercus kelloggii , San Bernandino NF, San Bernandino Co., CA.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
NEW LARVAL HOST RECORDS FOR NORTH AMERICAN
CERAMBYCIDAE ( COLEOPTERA )
JOSEF VLASAK 207 Silverbrook Dr. Schwenksville, PA 19473, U.S.A. josef_vlasak@merck.com

sec.title: ABSTRACT
sec.p:
New larval hosts for 59 North American Cerambycidae are presented. Host plants for
Astylopsis fascipennis Schiefer
,
Leptura obliterata deleta (LeConte)
,
Typocerus acuticauda acuticauda Casey
, and
Typocerus deceptus Knull
are documented for the first time.
Key Words: longhorn beetles, ecology, host plants, Nearctic

Beetles of the family Cerambycidae develop in plants. Host-plant associations for North American Cerambycidae have been summarized by Linsley and Chemsak (1997), and more information has been since added (Morris 2002; Szafranski 2002; Vlasak and Vlasakova 2002; Lingafelter 2003, 2007; Blodgett et al. 2005; Rice and Veal 2006; MacRae and Rice 2007; Swift 2008). Host-plant preferences range from highly selective species that may utilize a single host species or a genus to polyphagous species that can develop both in conifers and deciduous trees. Of the almost 1,000 Cerambycidae reported from North America (Monné et al . 2007), about 50% develop in deciduous trees and shrubs, ∼ 20% in conifers, ∼ 10% in various non-wooded plants (herbs, cacti, grasses), and the biology of about 20% remains to be discovered.

This work represents an addition to the knowledge of host-plant associations obtained by rearing Cerambycidae between 2001 and 2013, mostly in the eastern USA but in other parts of the country as well. Only host plants that, to the author’ s knowledge, have not been reported in the literature are presented.

sec.title: MATERIAL AND METHODS
sec.p:
Mature larvae or pupae were removed from the host plant and placed into small vials with a filter paper insert that helped to regulate moisture. Different types of vials were utilized, depending on the size of the specimen ( Fig. 1 ). For most species, 1.8-ml plastic vials ( Fisher Scientific , cat# 50-352-868 or similar) or 5-ml plastic vials ( USA Scientific , cat# 1505-7000 or similar) were used. Larger tubes, up to 50 ml, were used for large species. The vials were laid out sideways in a humidified chamber and kept at room temperature until the emergence of adult beetles. When only young larvae were encountered in the field, infested branches were collected and placed into plastic containers with fine netting over the top. Emergent adult beetles were collected on the netting. Reared specimens are deposited in the author’ s collection and are available upon request
.

The following resources were used for beetle identification: Linsley (1962a, b, 1963, 1964), Linsley and Chemsak (1972, 1976, 1984, 1995), Yanega (1996), and Lingafelter (2007). A stereomicroscope 10–30X (Amscope, ST-30-2L model) was used for identification. Nomenclature and classification follow that of Monné et al . (2007). Several field guides, namely Brockman and Merrilees (1996), Stuart and Sawyer (2001), and Tekiela (2008), as well as Internet resources were used for identification of the host plants. The following abbreviations are used: Co. – county; Mt. – mountain(s); NF – national forest; Pk. – park; SF – state forest; SP – state park.

sec.title: First Documented Larval Host Records
sec.p:
Astylopsis fascipennis Schiefer. The
larval host of this recently described species was previously unknown, although Schiefer (2000) stated that adults had been reared from miscellaneous dead limbs. I reared several individuals from dead branches of
Acer rubrum
L. ( Aceraceae ) at Virginia Beach , Virginia Beach Co. and Great Dismal Swamp,
Suffolk Co. , VA
.

Leptura obliterata deleta (LeConte)
. The western subspecies of
Leptura obliterata (Haldeman)
develops in a variety of coniferous trees, but the host plant of the rare eastern subspecies has not been reported to date. Larvae were collected in a mildly decayed fallen trunk of
Pinus rigida Mill.
( Pinaceae ) at Wharton SF, Burlington Co., NJ.

Typocerus acuticauda acuticauda Casey. Larvae
and pupae were collected in decaying trunks of
Quercus sp.
( Fagaceae ) at Swatara SP, Lebanon Co., PA and
Salix nigra Marshall (Salicacceae)
at Patuxent River SP, Montgomery Co., MD. The degree of the decay and larval habits were similar to those known for
Typocerus velutinus (Olivier)
.

Typocerus deceptus Knull. A
single pupa was found in a cutface of
Quercus sp.
at
Cunningham Falls SP
,
Frederick Co. , MD
. Dead parts of living trees are sought for development by some Cerambycidae , such as
Leptura anthracina LeConte. These
species are usually very selective for this type of a substrate. It remains unclear if
T. deceptus
solely utilizes this type of material or whether it could also develop in decaying wood as does the related
T. velutinus
.

sec.p:

.
Ficus sp.
( Moraceae ), dead stump, Everglades National Park, Miami-Dade Co., FL.

Ficus aurea Nutt. Two

Ficus sp.

sec.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
sec.p: I wish to thank to Ted MacRae for help with literature searches regarding published host plants.
